newsitem.title: IRAQ: Italy to set up interest section in Baghdad.
newsitem.headline: Italy to set up interest section in Baghdad.

text.p: Italy, seeking to revive its once lucrative trade with Iraq, will open an interest section in Baghdad next week, an Italian official said on Tuesday.

Antonio Loche, Secretary-General of the government-funded Italian Institute for Asia, said an Italian charge d'affaires would arrive in Baghdad early next week to head an interest section that would open under the Hungarian flag.
"Cesare Ragaglini will arrive on Saturday or Sunday as president of Italy's Interest Section in Baghdad," Loche told Reuters.
Loche said an Iraqi diplomat left for Rome on Monday to head Iraq's interest section, operating under the Sudanese flag.
"Qais al-Yakoubi who will head the Iraqi interest section in Rome has left Baghdad yesterday (Monday)," said Loche, who is invited by the ruling Baath party.
In February, Italy sent a mission to Iraq to assess possibilities of opening an interest section in Baghdad working under the Hungarian embassy.
Iraq severed diplomatic ties with Italy and other Arab and Western countries which took part in the U.S.-led military coalition which drove Iraqi troops out of Kuwait in 1991.
Scores of Italian businessmen and traders have flocked to Baghdad recently to secure deals in the lucrative market. Italy was Iraq's fourth trading partner before the Gulf crisis.
Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini announced in July that the planned interest section would be opened but gave no date.

Loche, who met several Iraqi officials including Deputy Prime Minister Tareq Aziz, said Italian companies had obtained permission from the U.N. sanctions committee to send to Iraq in December $130,000 worth of medicine and medical equipment.

Iraq is under stringent U.N. trade sanctions imposed on it after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. The curbs include a ban in Iraq's oil exports and imports of all commodities except for food and medicine, for which Iraq has little cash to pay for.

On May 20, Iraq and the U.N. signed an "oil-for-food" deal allowing it to sell $2 billion worth of oil to buy urgent needs. The long-awaited agreement has been stalled because of the inter-Kurdish fighting in northern Iraq.
Loche said that 30 Italian firms would organise a medical fair in Baghdad on December 14 to 18.
Last June, representatives of 35 Italian firms discussed in Baghdad possible trade deals with Iraq in accordance with the oil pact.
"So far, Italian companies have not signed any contract with Iraq, but they signed several cooperation minutes," Loche said.
